term_definitions.items: Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Name in free text unstructured format.
Name previously used by this person.
Name given to this person at birth.
Other name used by this person.
Name used by this persion before marriage.
The date interval at which this name was valid.
The prefix or title used by the subject.
Additional term used following a person name.
The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.
The name by which the subject is officially registered.
The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier.
Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.
Personal or organisational telephone, fax, and email details.
One or more telecoms contacts for an individual.
A structure for telephone numbers composed of separately identifiable elements. ENV13606-4:2000 7.11.18.
Telecom mechanism e.g. telephone, facsimile, pager etc. ENV 13606-4:2000 7.11.19.
A qualifier for a telecom contact, describing its context e.g. 'Work', 'Home'. ENV 13606 - 4:2000 7.11.19.
Details about a contact person within organisation.
Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party.
Name in free text unstructured format.
Name previously used by this person.
Name given to this person at birth.
Other name used by this person.
Name used by this persion before marriage.
The date interval at which this name was valid.
The prefix or title used by the subject.
Additional term used following a person name.
The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes.
The name by which the subject is officially registered.
The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier.
Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified.
Personal or organisational telephone, fax, and email details.
One or more telecoms contacts for an individual.
A structure for telephone numbers composed of separately identifiable elements. ENV13606-4:2000 7.11.18.
Telecom mechanism e.g. telephone, facsimile, pager etc. ENV 13606-4:2000 7.11.19.
A qualifier for a telecom contact, describing its context e.g. 'Work', 'Home'. ENV 13606 - 4:2000 7.11.19.
Details about a contact person within organisation.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot. Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.
Any timed measurement of height or body length.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.
Description of the device used to measure height or body length.
Height is measured standing on both feet with weight distributed evenly, heels together and both buttocks and heels in contact with a vertical back board.
Comment about the measurement of body height/length.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body height/length eg noting of amputation.
Length is measured in a fully extended, recumbent position with the pelvis flat, legs extended and feet flexed.
Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Description of the state of dress of the person at the time of weighing.
Clothing which may add significantly to weight, including shoes.
Clothing which will not add to weight significantly.
Wearing only a nappy - can add significant weight.
Comment about the measurement of weight.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of body weight eg timing in menstrual cycle, timing of recent bowel motion or noting of amputation.

item.list: Relevant Medical History and Concurrent Conditions

term_definitions.items: The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Relevant Medical History and Concurrent Conditions
Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care.
Structured detail about the individual's story or patient's history.
For example: a specific symptom such as nausea or pain; an event such as a fall off a bicycle; or an issue such as a desire to quit using tobacco.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Details of a medication or component of a medication, including details of any specific constituents.
The component consists of a number of separate products which are pre-packaged by the manufacturer, for example Canesten Combi.
The unit which is associated with the Strength value.
For example: 'mg/ml', '%', 'mg/tablet', 'µg/inhalation'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The expiry date and/or time of the medication normally as documented by the manufacturer but may be set by the individual preparing an ad hoc mixture.

For example: '2017-05-23'. This is intended for the date or time as given by the manufacturer or individual preparing the mixture. Any other form of expiry date, such as time from production or depending on storage environment, can be inserted using a specific CLUSTER archetype in the Substance Details slot or added as part of the Description.
The formulation or presentation of the medication.
For example: "tablet", "capsule", "cream", "infusion fluid". Coding of the form with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The chemical has a known and desired effect which is positive.
The chemical is inactive but aids the therapeutic effect of another ingredient.
The chemical is inactive and is added as a helper substance.
The value of the strength of the medication, as a real number, and associated with the Strength unit.
Details of an ingredient or product used to make up a mixed pack, preparation or infusion.
This is not normally required other than where an ad-hoc mixture or infusion is being described.
The role of the constituent within the mixture or infusion.
The name of the medication component.

For example: "Zinacef 750 mg powder" or "cefuroxim". This item should be coded if possible, using for example RxNorm, DM+D, Australian Medicines Terminology or FEST. Usage of component name will vary according to context of use. For example: This element may be omitted where the name of the medication is recorded in the parent INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetype, and this archetype is only used to record that the form must be or was "liquid".
A text description of the component where it is not possible to describe this fully using numerical strengths and amounts.
This slot is intended to be used to recursively add details about the constituent using this archetype.
Further details about the medication preparation.
For example: Detailed information about the drug class or intended routes.
The nature of the medication or medication component, with regard to manufacturing and number of ingredients.
For example: "Co-codamol" is a Combination product, while "Morphine 60 mg + Haloperidol 2 mg + Midazolam 5 mg" is an Ad-hoc mixture, whose composition is fully specified within the order.
The component is composed of a mixture of ingredients specified within the order. These are typically prepared by pharmacy or ward personnel to suit individual patients.
The component consists of a number of active ingredients which are pre-combined into a single form such as a tablet, cream or powder by the manufacturer, for example Co-codamol.
The component is a manufactured product containing a single active ingredient.
The component is an individual ingredient of the medication. This term is used when the arcehtype is used recursively, to describe the individual ingredients of a medication.
An alternate but equivalent representation of the amount of the constituent.
For example: '5 mg' where the Constituent amount is '1 ml' as an alternate ingredient amount for a substance with strength '5mg/1ml'.
The identifier assigned to the batch of medications by the manufacturer during production.
The strength of a mixture such as a solution or cream.

Some medications are manufactured or prepared as packs of for example solutions or creams, where the entire pack is intended to be used as a single dose. The strength of such medications is often given as the amount of active ingredient in the amount of the entire pack. For example: "2 mg/0.5 ml", "5 mg/10 g" or "10 ml/500 ml".
The amount of active substance in the total amount of mixture.

The active substance amount is usually given using mass, volume or arbitrary units. For example: "5 mg", "100 ml", "20 IU". Where a preparation strength is described as "5 mg/10 g", "5 mg" is the active substance amount.
The total amount of mixture, including both active substance and helper substances such as diluents.
The mixture amount is usually given using mass or volume units. For example: "5 g", "100 ml". Where a preparation strength is described as "5 mg/10 g", "10 g" is the total mixture amount.
Structured information about the intended timing of a therapeutic or diagnostic activity within any 24 hour period.
The frequency as number of times per time period that the activity is to take place.
For example: "4 times per day" or "3 to 4 times per hour".
A specific time or interval of time when the activity should occur.
The time interval or minimum and maximum range of an interval between each scheduled activity.
For example: "Every 4 hours" or "Every 4 to 6 hours".
Is exact timing of the activity critical to effectiveness, or patient safety or wellbeing?
For example when administering antiparkinson medications.
Record as True if the activity should only occur when the "'As required' criterion" is met.
Termed 'PRN' ("pro re nata", latin: "as the situation arises") or 'PN' ("per necessare", latin: "when required") in some cultures.
The condition which triggers an 'As required' activity.
The name of the event that triggers the activity to take place.

For example: "Before each meal", "at bedtime", "in the morning". It is understood that these event names may not equate to the same exact times in different cultures. Coding with a terminology, for example HL7 FHIR Named events, is recommended where appropriate.
Text description of the daily timing. This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for different timings without necessarily specifying the timings in a structured way.
A cycle of activity where an on-off pattern is required.
For example: "Apply an ice pack on for 20 minutes, off for an hour, repeat".
The period of time for which the activity should take place.
The period of time for which the activity should NOT take place.
The number of repetitions of the on/off cycle.
A specific, named time event that the activity should occur in relation to.
The period of time before or after the named event when the activity should take place. Negative durations can be used to signify that the activity should take place before the event.
For example: '30 minutes after meal = meal + 30 minutes', '2 hours before bedtime = bedtime -2 hours'.
The combination of a medication amount and administration timing for a single day, in the context of a medication order or medication management.

For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.
Structured details about the timing pattern for a single day.
The period of time over which a single dose of the medication or vaccine should be administered.
The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered.
For example: '200 ml/h'. Use the text data type to record non- or semi-quantifiable instructions.
The formula used to calculate the dose amount or administration rate where this is dependent on some other factor, such as body weight or surface area.

For example: '10mg/kg/day'. The result of this formula would normally be held in Dose amount/unit or Administration rate/duration. Where clinical measurements such as body weight is used in the dose calculation, a LINK attribute should used to specify which particular measurement has been used.
The value of the amount of medication administered at one time, as a real number, or range of real numbers, and associated with the Dose unit.
The unit which is associated with the Dose amount.
For example: 'tablet','mg'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The intended position of this dosage within the overall sequence of dosages.

For example: '1', '2', '3'. Where multiple dosages are expressed, the 'Pattern sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab in the morning, (2) 2 tab at 2pm, (3) 1 tab at night.
An alternate representation of the value of the amount of medication administered at one time, as a real number, or range of real numbers, and associated with the Dose unit.

For example, can be used to represent a unit-dose based value such as 'tabs', when the Dose amount is expressed as an SI unit such as 'mg', or where it is required to express the total amount of an infusion as well as the dose amount of the active ingredient.
The unit which is associated with the Alternate dose amount.

For example: "Apply ointment to affected area until it glistens". This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for increasing/tapering dosages without necessarily specifying the doses in a structured way.
Overall summary of the medication course.
The overall status of this order.
*The data at which the medication course was first ordered or recommended. (en)
*The date at which the medication was first issued. 'Issued' refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication. (en)
*The date at which the medication prescription was last issued. This refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication. (en)

*The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues. (en)

*The data at which the medication was last authorised.The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues. Authorisation is generally only given for a limited period or limited number of issues, after which re-authorisation is required. (en)
*The date at which the medicaton was first physically dispensed. (en)
*The date at which the medication was last dispensed. (en)
*The date at which the medication was discontinued. (en)
*The date at which the medication was authorised or re-authorised. (en)
*The date at which a medication prescription was issued i.e the physical or electronic prescription token was created. (en)
*The date at which a medication was dispensed. (en)
*The date at which a medication was administered. (en)
*The data at which administration of a medication was withheld or suspended. (en)
*The date at which the medication order was reviewed. (en)
*The date at which the medication order was last reviewed. (en)
*The date at which the medication instruction was modified. (en)
This is a medication that has previously been issued, dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued.
A medication which was ordered or authorised but has been cancelled prior to being issued, dispensed or adiminstered.
The medication course has been completed.
This medication order has been superseded by another.
Actions reuulting from the order are to be temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called 'on-hold'.
The medication order has been made but further processes e.g. sign-off or verification are required before it becomes actionable.
Outcome of Reaction / Event at the Time of Last Observation
Identification of the Country Where the Reaction / Event Occurred
Date of End of Reaction / Event
Indication as Reported by the Primary Source
Risk of harmful or undesirable physiological response which is unique to an individual and associated with exposure to a substance.

Substances include, but are not limited to: a therapeutic substance administered correctly at an appropriate dosage for the individual; food; material derived from plants or animals; or venom from insect stings.
Identification of a substance, or substance class, that is considered to put the individual at risk of an adverse reaction event.

Both an individual substance and a substance class are valid entries in 'Substance'. A substance may be a compound of simpler substances, for example a medicinal product. If the value in 'Substance' is an individual substance, it may be duplicated in 'Specific substance'. It is strongly recommended that both 'Substance' and 'Specific substance' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. For example: Snomed CT, DM+D, RxNorm, NDFRT, ATC, New Zealand Universal List of Medicines and Australian Medicines Terminology. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.
Additional narrative about the propensity for the adverse reaction, not captured in other fields.

For example: including reason for flagging a 'Criticality' of 'High risk'; and instructions related to future exposure or administration of the Substance, such as administration within an Intensive Care Unit or under corticosteroid cover.
Details about each adverse reaction event linked to exposure to the identified 'Substance'.
Identification of the substance considered to be responsible for the specific adverse reaction event.

For example: 'Amoxycillin'. Only an individual substance is a valid entry in 'Specific substance'. A substance may be a compound of simpler substances, for example a medicinal product. If the value in 'Substance' is an individual substance and not a substance class, then it may be duplicated in this data element. It is strongly recommended that 'Specific substance' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. For example: RxNorm, Snomed CT, DM+D, NDFRT, ICD-9, ICD-10, UNI, ATC and CPT. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.
Clinical symptoms and/or signs that are observed or associated with the adverse reaction.

Manifestation can be expressed as a single word, phrase or brief description. For example: nausea, rash. 'No reaction'may be appropriate where a previous reaction has been noted but the reaction did not re-occur after further exposure. It is preferable that 'Manifestation' should be coded with a terminology, where possible. The values entered here may be used to display on an application screen as part of a list of adverse reactions, as recommended in the UK NHS CUI guidelines.
Terminologies commonly used include, but are not limited to, SNOMED-CT or ICD10.
Narrative description about the adverse reaction as a whole, including details of the manifestation if required.
Narrative description about exposure to the identified 'Specific substance'.
Record of the date and/or time of the first exposure to the Substance for this Reaction Event.

Exposure can be more complicated by more than one exposure events leading to a reaction. Further details about the nature of the exposure can be provided by use of additional archetypes in the 'Exposure details' SLOT or as text in the 'Exposure description'.
Statement about the degree of clinical certainty that the identified 'Specific substance' was the cause of the 'Manifestation' in this reaction event.
A reasonable level of clinical certainty that the reaction was caused by the identified 'Specific substance'.
The total amount of time the individual was exposed to the identified 'Specific substance'.
Record of the date and/or time of the onset of the reaction.
The total amount of time that the manifestation of the adverse reaction persisted.
Additional details about the adverse reaction, including anatomical location and Common Toxicity Criteria, can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT.

May include structured detail about symptoms; the anatomical location of the manifestation; grading, classification or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events; or the Multimedia CLUSTER archetype. [Note: FHIR - These would be extensions as specified in a profile.]
Additional narrative about the adverse reaction event not captured in other fields.
Narrative description about the clinical management provided.
Additional structured details required for reporting to regulatory bodies can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT.
Has the adverse reaction ever been reported to a regulatory body?
Link to an adverse reaction Report sent to a regulatory body.
Link to further information about the presentation and findings that exist elsewhere in the health record, including allergy test reports.
For example, presenting symptoms, examination findings, diagnosis etc. [Note: FHIR,DAM: Maps to Sensitivity Test.]
Narrative about the adverse reaction report or reporting process.
For example, the reason for non-reporting.
Identification of the underlying physiological mechanism for the adverse reaction.

Immune-mediated responses have been traditionally regarded as an indicator for escalation of significant future risk. Contemporary knowledge suggests that some reactions previously thought to be immune are actually non-immune and still carry life threatening risk.
Immunological testing may provide supporting evidence for the mechanism and causative substance , but no tests are 100% sensitive or specific for a sensitivity.
It is acknowledged that most clinicians will NOT be able to distinguish the mechanism of any specific reaction. However this data element is included because many legacy systems have captured this attribute.
Immune mediated reaction, including allergic reactions and hypersensitivities.
A non-immune mediated reaction, which can include pseudo-allergic reactions, side effects, intolerances, drug toxicities (for example, to Gentamicin).
Date when the propensity or the reaction event was updated.
Note: maps to recordedDate in FHIR.
Assertion about the certainty of the propensity, or potential future risk, of the identified 'Substance' to cause a reaction.

Decision support would typically raise alerts for 'Suspected', 'Likely', 'Confirmed', and ignore a 'Refuted' reaction. Clinical systems may choose not to display Adverse reaction entries with a
'Refuted' status in the Adverse Reaction List.
However, 'Refuted' may be useful for reconciliation of the adverse reaction list or when communicating between systems
. Some implementations may choose to make this field mandatory. 'Resolved' may be used variably across systems, depending on clinical use and context - there appears to be differing opinion whether this should still be used to raise potential alerts or to display in an Adverse Reaction List. The free text data type will allow for local variation by enabling other value sets to be applied to this data element in a template - in this situation it is recommended that values should be coded using a terminology.
A reasonable level of certainty about the propensity for a reaction to the identified 'Substance'.
A high level of certainty about the propensity for a reaction to the identified 'Substance', which may include clinical evidence by testing or re-challenge.
The propensity for a reaction to the identified 'Substance' has been clinically reassessed or has been disproved with a high level of clinical certainty by re-exposure or deliberate challenge.
The previously known reaction to the identified 'Substance' has been clinically reassessed and considered no longer to be an active risk.
Clinical assessment of the severity of the reaction event as a whole, potentially considering multiple different manifestations.

It is acknowledged that this assessment is very subjective. There may be some some specific practice domains where objective scales have been applied. Objective scales can be included in this model using the 'Reaction details' Cluster.
A low level of clinical certainty that the reaction was caused by the identified 'Specific substance'.

Additional details about exposure to the 'Specific substance', especially in situations where there may have been multiple or cumulative exposures can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT.
Structured details about reports that have been forwarded to regulatory bodies.
An indication of the potential for critical system organ damage or life threatening consequence.
This can be regarded as a predictive judgement of a 'worst case scenario'. In most contexts 'Low' would be regarded as the default value.

Exposure to substance unlikely to result in critical system organ damage or life threatening consequence. Future exposure to the identified 'Substance' should be considered a relative contra-indication in normal clinical circumstances.

Exposure to substance may result in critical organ system damage or life threatening consequence. Future exposure to the identified 'Substance' should be considered an absolute contra-indication in normal clinical circumstances.
Identification of the route by which the subject was exposed to the identified 'Specific substance'.
Coding of the Route of Exposure with a terminology should be used wherever possible.
Details about the provenance of the information can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT.

This SLOT is intended for to provide details about the source of information for this particular 'Reaction event'. Details about the source of information for the entire 'Adverse reaction risk' should be recorded using the 'Information Provider' reference model attribute.
The date and/or time of the onset of the last known occurrence of a reaction event.

This date may be be a duplicate of the most recent 'Onset of reaction' date. Where a textual representation of the date of last occurrence is required e.g 'In Childhood, '10 years ago' the Comment element should be used.
A high level of clinical certainty that the reaction was due to the identified 'Substance', which may include clinical evidence by testing or re-challenge.
Additional structured details about clinical management for this reaction event can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT.

This data element has been included because it is currently being captured in some clinical systems. This data can be derived from the Substance where coding systems are used, and is effectively redundant in that situation.
Any substance consumed to provide nutritional support for the body, such as peanut or egg.
Any substance administered to achieve a physiological effect.
Any other substance encountered including venom, latex and other environmental substances.
Unable to assess with information available.
Date that the report was sent to the regulatory authority.
The physiological mechanism could not be determined.
A low level of clinical certainty about the propensity of a reaction to the identified 'Substance'.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Examine a patient after the incident
Participated in the testimonial of entanglement
The subsequent location for the reported event.
Other participants involved in the clinical safety event.
The clinical role of the event participant (occupation type).
The role of the participant in the context of the reported event.
The type of medication safety report.
Identifier of the original order session which initiated this report.
Document to communicate information regarding a safety issue for an individual clinical case.
Identifier of the order group which initiated this report.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
The report is incomplete. Further updates should be expected.
The final version of the report. Further updates are not anticipated.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Identifier of the order group which initiated this report.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.

items.items: *The subsequent location for the reported event.(en)
*Other participants involved in the clinical safety event.(en)
*The clinical role of the event participant.(en)
*The role of the participant in the context of the reported event.(en)
*Identifier of the original order session which initiated this report.(en)
*Document to communicate information regarding a safety issue for an individual clinical case.(en)
*Identifier of the order group which initiated this report.(en)
*The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.(en)
*The report is incomplete. Further updates should be expected.(en)
*The final version of the report. Further updates are not anticipated.(en)
*Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.(en)
*Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.(en)
*Identifier of the order group which initiated this report.(en)
*The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.(en)
*The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.(en)
Naprav s katero se je izvedla meritev
Višina/dolžina pacienta, izmerjena od vrha glave do podplatov na nogah
*Any timed measurement of height or body length.(en)
Višina/dolžina pacienta, izmerjena od vrha glave do podplatov na nogah
Pozicija pacienta, ko se izvaja meritev
*The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer. (en)
*Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time. (en)
*Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care. (en)
*Structured detail about the individual's story or patient's history. (en)
For example: a specific symptom such as nausea or pain; an event such as a fall off a bicycle; or an issue such as a desire to quit using tobacco.
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
For example: Local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.

ID časa zdravljenja, ki mu pripada ta composition. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.(en)
ID časa zdravljenja na oddelku, ki mu pripada ta composition.
ID portleta v katerem so shranjene informacije o shranjenom composition-u.
Naziv organizacije iz katere prihaja pošiljatelj
*Details about a contact person within organisation. (en)
*Personal or organisational telephone, fax, and email details. (en)
*One or more telecoms contacts for an individual. (en)
*A structure for telephone numbers composed of separately identifiable elements. ENV13606-4:2000 7.11.18. (en)
*Telecom mechanism e.g. telephone, facsimile, pager etc. ENV 13606-4:2000 7.11.19. (en)
*A qualifier for a telecom contact, describing its context e.g. 'Work', 'Home'. ENV 13606 - 4:2000 7.11.19. (en)
*Details of personal name of an individual, provider or third party. (en)
*Name given to this person at birth. (en)
*Name used by this persion before marriage. (en)
*The date interval at which this name was valid. (en)
*The prefix or title used by the subject. (en)
*Additional term used following a person name. (en)
*The name used by the subject for business or professional purposes. (en)
*The name by which the subject is officially registered. (en)
*The subject’s name as it is to be used for reporting, when used with a specific identifier. (en)
*Indicates that this is the name by which a person chooses to be identified. (en)
*Risk of harmful or undesirable physiological response which is unique to an individual and associated with exposure to a substance. (en)

Substances include, but are not limited to: a therapeutic substance administered correctly at an appropriate dosage for the individual; food; material derived from plants or animals; or venom from insect stings.
*Identification of a substance, or substance class, that is considered to put the individual at risk of an adverse reaction event. (en)

Both an individual substance and a substance class are valid entries in 'Substance'. A substance may be a compound of simpler substances, for example a medicinal product. If the value in 'Substance' is an individual substance, it may be duplicated in 'Specific substance'. It is strongly recommended that both 'Substance' and 'Specific substance' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. For example: Snomed CT, DM+D, RxNorm, NDFRT, ATC, New Zealand Universal List of Medicines and Australian Medicines Terminology. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.
*Additional narrative about the propensity for the adverse reaction, not captured in other fields. (en)

For example: including reason for flagging a 'Criticality' of 'High risk'; and instructions related to future exposure or administration of the Substance, such as administration within an Intensive Care Unit or under corticosteroid cover.
*Details about each adverse reaction event linked to exposure to the identified 'Substance'. (en)
*Identification of the substance considered to be responsible for the specific adverse reaction event. (en)

For example: 'Amoxycillin'. Only an individual substance is a valid entry in 'Specific substance'. A substance may be a compound of simpler substances, for example a medicinal product. If the value in 'Substance' is an individual substance and not a substance class, then it may be duplicated in this data element. It is strongly recommended that 'Specific substance' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. For example: RxNorm, Snomed CT, DM+D, NDFRT, ICD-9, ICD-10, UNI, ATC and CPT. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.
*Clinical symptoms and/or signs that are observed or associated with the adverse reaction. (en)

Manifestation can be expressed as a single word, phrase or brief description. For example: nausea, rash. 'No reaction'may be appropriate where a previous reaction has been noted but the reaction did not re-occur after further exposure. It is preferable that 'Manifestation' should be coded with a terminology, where possible. The values entered here may be used to display on an application screen as part of a list of adverse reactions, as recommended in the UK NHS CUI guidelines.
Terminologies commonly used include, but are not limited to, SNOMED-CT or ICD10.
*Narrative description about the adverse reaction as a whole, including details of the manifestation if required. (en)
*Narrative description about exposure to the identified 'Specific substance'. (en)
*Record of the date and/or time of the first exposure to the Substance for this Reaction Event. (en)

Exposure can be more complicated by more than one exposure events leading to a reaction. Further details about the nature of the exposure can be provided by use of additional archetypes in the 'Exposure details' SLOT or as text in the 'Exposure description'.
*Statement about the degree of clinical certainty that the identified 'Specific substance' was the cause of the 'Manifestation' in this reaction event. (en)
*A reasonable level of clinical certainty that the reaction was caused by the identified 'Specific substance'. (en)
*The total amount of time the individual was exposed to the identified 'Specific substance'. (en)
*Record of the date and/or time of the onset of the reaction. (en)
*The total amount of time that the manifestation of the adverse reaction persisted. (en)
*Additional details about the adverse reaction, including anatomical location and Common Toxicity Criteria, can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT. (en)

May include structured detail about symptoms; the anatomical location of the manifestation; grading, classification or formal severity assessments such as Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events; or the Multimedia CLUSTER archetype. [Note: FHIR - These would be extensions as specified in a profile.]
*Additional narrative about the adverse reaction event not captured in other fields. (en)
*Narrative description about the clinical management provided. (en)
*Additional structured details required for reporting to regulatory bodies can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT. (en)
*Has the adverse reaction ever been reported to a regulatory body? (en)
*Link to an adverse reaction Report sent to a regulatory body. (en)
*Link to further information about the presentation and findings that exist elsewhere in the health record, including allergy test reports. (en)
For example, presenting symptoms, examination findings, diagnosis etc. [Note: FHIR,DAM: Maps to Sensitivity Test.]
*Narrative about the adverse reaction report or reporting process. (en)
For example, the reason for non-reporting.
*Identification of the underlying physiological mechanism for the adverse reaction. (en)

Immune-mediated responses have been traditionally regarded as an indicator for escalation of significant future risk. Contemporary knowledge suggests that some reactions previously thought to be immune are actually non-immune and still carry life threatening risk.
Immunological testing may provide supporting evidence for the mechanism and causative substance , but no tests are 100% sensitive or specific for a sensitivity.
It is acknowledged that most clinicians will NOT be able to distinguish the mechanism of any specific reaction. However this data element is included because many legacy systems have captured this attribute.
*Immune mediated reaction, including allergic reactions and hypersensitivities. (en)
*A non-immune mediated reaction, which can include pseudo-allergic reactions, side effects, intolerances, drug toxicities (for example, to Gentamicin). (en)
Datum, ko je poročevalec prejel zadnje podatke o NUZ
*Date when the propensity or the reaction event was updated. (en)
Note: maps to recordedDate in FHIR.
*Assertion about the certainty of the propensity, or potential future risk, of the identified 'Substance' to cause a reaction. (en)

Decision support would typically raise alerts for 'Suspected', 'Likely', 'Confirmed', and ignore a 'Refuted' reaction. Clinical systems may choose not to display Adverse reaction entries with a
'Refuted' status in the Adverse Reaction List.
However, 'Refuted' may be useful for reconciliation of the adverse reaction list or when communicating between systems
. Some implementations may choose to make this field mandatory. 'Resolved' may be used variably across systems, depending on clinical use and context - there appears to be differing opinion whether this should still be used to raise potential alerts or to display in an Adverse Reaction List. The free text data type will allow for local variation by enabling other value sets to be applied to this data element in a template - in this situation it is recommended that values should be coded using a terminology.
*A reasonable level of certainty about the propensity for a reaction to the identified 'Substance'. (en)
*A high level of certainty about the propensity for a reaction to the identified 'Substance', which may include clinical evidence by testing or re-challenge. (en)
*The propensity for a reaction to the identified 'Substance' has been clinically reassessed or has been disproved with a high level of clinical certainty by re-exposure or deliberate challenge. (en)
*The previously known reaction to the identified 'Substance' has been clinically reassessed and considered no longer to be an active risk. (en)
*Clinical assessment of the severity of the reaction event as a whole, potentially considering multiple different manifestations. (en)

It is acknowledged that this assessment is very subjective. There may be some some specific practice domains where objective scales have been applied. Objective scales can be included in this model using the 'Reaction details' Cluster.
*A low level of clinical certainty that the reaction was caused by the identified 'Specific substance'. (en)

*Additional details about exposure to the 'Specific substance', especially in situations where there may have been multiple or cumulative exposures can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT. (en)
*Structured details about reports that have been forwarded to regulatory bodies. (en)
*An indication of the potential for critical system organ damage or life threatening consequence. (en)
This can be regarded as a predictive judgement of a 'worst case scenario'. In most contexts 'Low' would be regarded as the default value.

*Exposure to substance unlikely to result in critical system organ damage or life threatening consequence. Future exposure to the identified 'Substance' should be considered a relative contra-indication in normal clinical circumstances. (en)

*Exposure to substance may result in critical organ system damage or life threatening consequence. Future exposure to the identified 'Substance' should be considered an absolute contra-indication in normal clinical circumstances. (en)
*Identification of the route by which the subject was exposed to the identified 'Specific substance'. (en)
Coding of the Route of Exposure with a terminology should be used wherever possible.
*Details about the provenance of the information can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT. (en)

This SLOT is intended for to provide details about the source of information for this particular 'Reaction event'. Details about the source of information for the entire 'Adverse reaction risk' should be recorded using the 'Information Provider' reference model attribute.
*The date and/or time of the onset of the last known occurrence of a reaction event. (en)

This date may be be a duplicate of the most recent 'Onset of reaction' date. Where a textual representation of the date of last occurrence is required e.g 'In Childhood, '10 years ago' the Comment element should be used.
*A high level of clinical certainty that the reaction was due to the identified 'Substance', which may include clinical evidence by testing or re-challenge. (en)
*Additional structured details about clinical management for this reaction event can be provided by inclusion of specific archetypes in this SLOT. (en)

This data element has been included because it is currently being captured in some clinical systems. This data can be derived from the Substance where coding systems are used, and is effectively redundant in that situation.
*Any substance consumed to provide nutritional support for the body, such as peanut or egg. (en)
*Any substance administered to achieve a physiological effect. (en)
*Any other substance encountered including venom, latex and other environmental substances. (en)
Datum, ko je poročevalec prvič izvedel za NUZ
*Date that the report was sent to the regulatory authority. (en)
*The physiological mechanism could not be determined. (en)
*A low level of clinical certainty about the propensity of a reaction to the identified 'Substance'. (en)
*Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms. (en)
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
*The data at which the medication course was first ordered or recommended. (en)
*The date at which the medication was first issued. 'Issued' refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication. (en)
*The date at which the medication prescription was last issued. This refers to the prescription 'token' electronic or paper which authorises supply of a medication. (en)

*The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues. (en)

*The data at which the medication was last authorised.The date at which the medication was first authorised.For a repeat prescription, authorisation refers to the creation of the repeat prescription 'master' which is followed by the production of one or more prescription issues. Authorisation is generally only given for a limited period or limited number of issues, after which re-authorisation is required. (en)
*The date at which the medicaton was first physically dispensed. (en)
*The date at which the medication was last dispensed. (en)
*The date at which the medication was discontinued. (en)
*The date at which the medication was authorised or re-authorised. (en)
*The date at which a medication prescription was issued i.e the physical or electronic prescription token was created. (en)
*The date at which a medication was dispensed. (en)
*The date at which a medication was administered. (en)
*The data at which administration of a medication was withheld or suspended. (en)
*The date at which the medication order was reviewed. (en)
*The date at which the medication order was last reviewed. (en)
*The date at which the medication instruction was modified. (en)
*This is a medication that has previously been issued, dispensed or administered but has now been discontinued. (en)
*A medication which was ordered or authorised but has been cancelled prior to being issued, dispensed or adiminstered. (en)
*This medication order has been superseded by another. (en)
*Actions reuulting from the order are to be temporarily halted, but are expected to continue later. May also be called 'on-hold'. (en)
*The medication order has been made but further processes e.g. sign-off or verification are required before it becomes actionable. (en)
*Details of a medication or component of a medication, including details of any specific constituents. (en)
*The component consists of a number of separate products which are pre-packaged by the manufacturer, for example Canesten Combi. (en)
*The unit which is associated with the Strength value. (en)
For example: 'mg/ml', '%', 'mg/tablet', 'µg/inhalation'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
*The expiry date and/or time of the medication normally as documented by the manufacturer but may be set by the individual preparing an ad hoc mixture. (en)

For example: '2017-05-23'. This is intended for the date or time as given by the manufacturer or individual preparing the mixture. Any other form of expiry date, such as time from production or depending on storage environment, can be inserted using a specific CLUSTER archetype in the Substance Details slot or added as part of the Description.
*The formulation or presentation of the medication. (en)
For example: "tablet", "capsule", "cream", "infusion fluid". Coding of the form with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
*The chemical has a known and desired effect which is positive. (en)
*The chemical is inactive but aids the therapeutic effect of another ingredient. (en)
*The chemical is inactive and is added as a helper substance. (en)
*The value of the strength of the medication, as a real number, and associated with the Strength unit. (en)
*Details of an ingredient or product used to make up a mixed pack, preparation or infusion. (en)
This is not normally required other than where an ad-hoc mixture or infusion is being described.
*The role of the constituent within the mixture or infusion. (en)

For example: "Zinacef 750 mg powder" or "cefuroxim". This item should be coded if possible, using for example RxNorm, DM+D, Australian Medicines Terminology or FEST. Usage of component name will vary according to context of use. For example: This element may be omitted where the name of the medication is recorded in the parent INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetype, and this archetype is only used to record that the form must be or was "liquid".
*A text description of the component where it is not possible to describe this fully using numerical strengths and amounts. (en)
This slot is intended to be used to recursively add details about the constituent using this archetype.
For example: Detailed information about the drug class or intended routes.
*The nature of the medication or medication component, with regard to manufacturing and number of ingredients. (en)
For example: "Co-codamol" is a Combination product, while "Morphine 60 mg + Haloperidol 2 mg + Midazolam 5 mg" is an Ad-hoc mixture, whose composition is fully specified within the order.
*The component is composed of a mixture of ingredients specified within the order. These are typically prepared by pharmacy or ward personnel to suit individual patients. (en)
*The component consists of a number of active ingredients which are pre-combined into a single form such as a tablet, cream or powder by the manufacturer, for example Co-codamol. (en)
*The component is a manufactured product containing a single active ingredient. (en)
*The component is an individual ingredient of the medication. This term is used when the arcehtype is used recursively, to describe the individual ingredients of a medication. (en)
*An alternate but equivalent representation of the amount of the constituent. (en)
For example: '5 mg' where the Constituent amount is '1 ml' as an alternate ingredient amount for a substance with strength '5mg/1ml'.
*The identifier assigned to the batch of medications by the manufacturer during production. (en)
*The strength of a mixture such as a solution or cream. (en)

Some medications are manufactured or prepared as packs of for example solutions or creams, where the entire pack is intended to be used as a single dose. The strength of such medications is often given as the amount of active ingredient in the amount of the entire pack. For example: "2 mg/0.5 ml", "5 mg/10 g" or "10 ml/500 ml".
*The amount of active substance in the total amount of mixture. (en)

The active substance amount is usually given using mass, volume or arbitrary units. For example: "5 mg", "100 ml", "20 IU". Where a preparation strength is described as "5 mg/10 g", "5 mg" is the active substance amount.
*The total amount of mixture, including both active substance and helper substances such as diluents. (en)
The mixture amount is usually given using mass or volume units. For example: "5 g", "100 ml". Where a preparation strength is described as "5 mg/10 g", "10 g" is the total mixture amount.
*The combination of a medication amount and administration timing for a single day, in the context of a medication order or medication management. (en)

For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.
*Structured details about the timing pattern for a single day. (en)
*The period of time over which a single dose of the medication or vaccine should be administered. (en)
*The rate at which the medication, such as an infusion, is to be administered. (en)
For example: '200 ml/h'. Use the text data type to record non- or semi-quantifiable instructions.
*The formula used to calculate the dose amount or administration rate where this is dependent on some other factor, such as body weight or surface area. (en)

For example: '10mg/kg/day'. The result of this formula would normally be held in Dose amount/unit or Administration rate/duration. Where clinical measurements such as body weight is used in the dose calculation, a LINK attribute should used to specify which particular measurement has been used.
*The value of the amount of medication administered at one time, as a real number, or range of real numbers, and associated with the Dose unit. (en)
*The unit which is associated with the Dose amount. (en)
For example: 'tablet','mg'. Coding of the dose unit with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
*The intended position of this dosage within the overall sequence of dosages. (en)

For example: '1', '2', '3'. Where multiple dosages are expressed, the 'Pattern sequence' makes the order in which they should be executed explicit. For example: (1) 1 tab in the morning, (2) 2 tab at 2pm, (3) 1 tab at night.
*An alternate representation of the value of the amount of medication administered at one time, as a real number, or range of real numbers, and associated with the Dose unit. (en)

For example, can be used to represent a unit-dose based value such as 'tabs', when the Dose amount is expressed as an SI unit such as 'mg', or where it is required to express the total amount of an infusion as well as the dose amount of the active ingredient.
*The unit which is associated with the Alternate dose amount. (en)

For example: "Apply ointment to affected area until it glistens". This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for increasing/tapering dosages without necessarily specifying the doses in a structured way.
Dolgotrajna ali izrazita nezmožnost ali invalidnost
Starostna skupina bolnika ob nastanku NUZ
*Structured information about the timing (intended or actual) of administration or use of a medicine, other therapeutic good or other intervention that is given on a scheduled basis.(en)
*The frequency as number of times per time period (limited to a single day) that the activity is to take place.(en)
*e.g. "4 times per day" or ""3 to 4 times per hour"(en)
*A specific time during a single day when the activity should occur.(en)
*The time interval between each scheduled activity, limited to a single day.(en)
*Is exact timing of the activity critical to patient safety or wellbeing?(en)
*The activity should only occur when the "as required" trigger condition is met.(en)
*The condition which triggers an 'as required' activity.(en)
*The name of the event that triggers the activity to take place.(en)

*For example: "Before each meal", "at bedtime", "in the morning". It is understood that these event names may not equate to the same exact times in different cultures. Coding with a terminology, for example HL7 FHIR Named events, is recommended where appropriate.(en)
*Text description of the daily timing. This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for different timings without necessarily specifying the timings in a structured way.(en)
*A cycle of activity where an on-off pattern is required.(en)
*e.g. 'apply patch for six hours, remove for 12 hours, repeat'(en)
*The period of time for which the activity should take place.(en)
*The period of time for which the activity should NOT take place.(en)
*The number of repetitions of the on/off cycle.(en)
*A specific, named time event that the activity should occur in relation to.(en)
*The period of time before or after the named event when the activity should take place. Negative durations can be used to signify that the activity should take place before the event.(en)
*For example: '30 minutes after meal = meal + 30 minutes', '2 hours before bedtime = bedtime -2 hours'.(en)
